30   package org.firstinspires.ftc.robotcontroller.external.samples;
31   
32   import android.app.Activity;
33   import android.graphics.Color;
34   import android.view.View;
35   
36   import com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.Disabled;
37   import com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.LinearOpMode;
38   import com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.TeleOp;
39   import com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.DistanceSensor;
40   import com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.NormalizedColorSensor;
41   import com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.NormalizedRGBA;
42   import com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.SwitchableLight;
43   
44   import org.firstinspires.ftc.robotcore.external.navigation.DistanceUnit;
45   
46   /**
47    * This is an example LinearOpMode that shows how to use a color sensor in a generic
48    * way, regardless of which particular make or model of color sensor is used. The Op Mode
49    * assumes that the color sensor is configured with a name of "sensor_color".
50    *
51    * There will be some variation in the values measured depending on the specific sensor you are using.
52    *
53    * You can increase the gain (a multiplier to make the sensor report higher values) by holding down
54    * the A button on the gamepad, and decrease the gain by holding down the B button on the gamepad.
55    *
56    * If the color sensor has a light which is controllable from software, you can use the X button on
57    * the gamepad to toggle the light on and off. The REV sensors don't support this, but instead have
58    * a physical switch on them to turn the light on and off, beginning with REV Color Sensor V2.
59    *
60    * If the color sensor also supports short-range distance measurements (usually via an infrared
61    * proximity sensor), the reported distance will be written to telemetry. As of September 2020,
62    * the only color sensors that support this are the ones from REV Robotics. These infrared proximity
63    * sensor measurements are only useful at very small distances, and are sensitive to ambient light
64    * and surface reflectivity. You should use a different sensor if you need precise distance measurements.
65    *
66    * Use Android Studio to Copy this Class, and Paste it into your team's code folder with a new name.
67    * Remove or comment out the @Disabled line to add this Op Mode to the Driver Station OpMode list
68    */
69   @TeleOp(name = "Sensor: Color", group = "Sensor")
70   @Disabled
71   public class SensorColor extends LinearOpMode {
72   
73     /** The colorSensor field will contain a reference to our color sensor hardware object */
74     NormalizedColorSensor colorSensor;
75   
76     /** The relativeLayout field is used to aid in providing interesting visual feedback
77      * in this sample application; you probably *don't* need this when you use a color sensor on your
78      * robot. Note that you won't see anything change on the Driver Station, only on the Robot Controller. */
79     View relativeLayout;
80   
81     /**
82      * The runOpMode() method is the root of this Op Mode, as it is in all LinearOpModes.
83      * Our implementation here, though is a bit unusual: we've decided to put all the actual work
84      * in the runSample() method rather than directly in runOpMode() itself. The reason we do that is
85      * that in this sample we're changing the background color of the robot controller screen as the
86      * Op Mode runs, and we want to be able to *guarantee* that we restore it to something reasonable
87      * and palatable when the Op Mode ends. The simplest way to do that is to use a try...finally
88      * block around the main, core logic, and an easy way to make that all clear was to separate
89      * the former from the latter in separate methods.
90      */
91     @Override public void runOpMode() {
92   
93       // Get a reference to the RelativeLayout so we can later change the background
94       // color of the Robot Controller app to match the hue detected by the RGB sensor.
95       int relativeLayoutId = hardwareMap.appContext.getResources().getIdentifier("RelativeLayout", "id", hardwareMap.appContext.getPackageName());
96       relativeLayout = ((Activity) hardwareMap.appContext).findViewById(relativeLayoutId);
97   
98       try {
99         runSample(); // actually execute the sample
100      } finally {
101        // On the way out, *guarantee* that the background is reasonable. It doesn't actually start off
102        // as pure white, but it's too much work to dig out what actually was used, and this is good
103        // enough to at least make the screen reasonable again.
104        // Set the panel back to the default color
105        relativeLayout.post(new Runnable() {
106          public void run() {
107            relativeLayout.setBackgroundColor(Color.WHITE);
108          }
109        });
110        }
111    }
112  
113    protected void runSample() {
114      // You can give the sensor a gain value, will be multiplied by the sensor's raw value before the
115      // normalized color values are calculated. Color sensors (especially the REV Color Sensor V3)
116      // can give very low values (depending on the lighting conditions), which only use a small part
117      // of the 0-1 range that is available for the red, green, and blue values. In brighter conditions,
118      // you should use a smaller gain than in dark conditions. If your gain is too high, all of the
119      // colors will report at or near 1, and you won't be able to determine what color you are
120      // actually looking at. For this reason, it's better to err on the side of a lower gain
121      // (but always greater than  or equal to 1).
122      float gain = 2;
123  
124      // Once per loop, we will update this hsvValues array. The first element (0) will contain the
125      // hue, the second element (1) will contain the saturation, and the third element (2) will
126      // contain the value. See http://web.archive.org/web/20190311170843/https://infohost.nmt.edu/tcc/help/pubs/colortheory/web/hsv.html
127      // for an explanation of HSV color.
128      final float[] hsvValues = new float[3];
129  
130      // xButtonPreviouslyPressed and xButtonCurrentlyPressed keep track of the previous and current
131      // state of the X button on the gamepad
132      boolean xButtonPreviouslyPressed = false;
133      boolean xButtonCurrentlyPressed = false;
134  
135      // Get a reference to our sensor object. It's recommended to use NormalizedColorSensor over
136      // ColorSensor, because NormalizedColorSensor consistently gives values between 0 and 1, while
137      // the values you get from ColorSensor are dependent on the specific sensor you're using.
138      colorSensor = hardwareMap.get(NormalizedColorSensor.class, "sensor_color");
139  
140      // If possible, turn the light on in the beginning (it might already be on anyway,
141      // we just make sure it is if we can).
142      if (colorSensor instanceof SwitchableLight) {
143        ((SwitchableLight)colorSensor).enableLight(true);
144      }
145  
146      // Wait for the start button to be pressed.
147      waitForStart();
148  
149      // Loop until we are asked to stop
150      while (opModeIsActive()) {
151        // Explain basic gain information via telemetry
152        telemetry.addLine("Hold the A button on gamepad 1 to increase gain, or B to decrease it.\n");
153        telemetry.addLine("Higher gain values mean that the sensor will report larger numbers for Red, Green, and Blue, and Value\n");
154  
155        // Update the gain value if either of the A or B gamepad buttons is being held
156        if (gamepad1.a) {
157          // Only increase the gain by a small amount, since this loop will occur multiple times per second.
158          gain += 0.005;
159        } else if (gamepad1.b && gain > 1) { // A gain of less than 1 will make the values smaller, which is not helpful.
160          gain -= 0.005;
161        }
162  
163        // Show the gain value via telemetry
164        telemetry.addData("Gain", gain);
165  
166        // Tell the sensor our desired gain value (normally you would do this during initialization,
167        // not during the loop)
168        colorSensor.setGain(gain);
169  
170        // Check the status of the X button on the gamepad
171        xButtonCurrentlyPressed = gamepad1.x;
172  
173        // If the button state is different than what it was, then act
174        if (xButtonCurrentlyPressed != xButtonPreviouslyPressed) {
175          // If the button is (now) down, then toggle the light
176          if (xButtonCurrentlyPressed) {
177            if (colorSensor instanceof SwitchableLight) {
178              SwitchableLight light = (SwitchableLight)colorSensor;
179              light.enableLight(!light.isLightOn());
180            }
181          }
182        }
183        xButtonPreviouslyPressed = xButtonCurrentlyPressed;
184  
185        // Get the normalized colors from the sensor
186        NormalizedRGBA colors = colorSensor.getNormalizedColors();
187  
188        /* Use telemetry to display feedback on the driver station. We show the red, green, and blue 
189         * normalized values from the sensor (in the range of 0 to 1), as well as the equivalent 
190         * HSV (hue, saturation and value) values. See http://web.archive.org/web/20190311170843/https://infohost.nmt.edu/tcc/help/pubs/colortheory/web/hsv.html 
191         * for an explanation of HSV color. */
192  
193        // Update the hsvValues array by passing it to Color.colorToHSV()
194        Color.colorToHSV(colors.toColor(), hsvValues);
195  
196        telemetry.addLine()
197                .addData("Red", "%.3f", colors.red)
198                .addData("Green", "%.3f", colors.green)
199                .addData("Blue", "%.3f", colors.blue);
200        telemetry.addLine()
201                .addData("Hue", "%.3f", hsvValues[0])
202                .addData("Saturation", "%.3f", hsvValues[1])
203                .addData("Value", "%.3f", hsvValues[2]);
204        telemetry.addData("Alpha", "%.3f", colors.alpha);
205  
206        /* If this color sensor also has a distance sensor, display the measured distance. 
207         * Note that the reported distance is only useful at very close range, and is impacted by 
208         * ambient light and surface reflectivity. */
209        if (colorSensor instanceof DistanceSensor) {
210          telemetry.addData("Distance (cm)", "%.3f", ((DistanceSensor) colorSensor).getDistance(DistanceUnit.CM));
211        }
212  
213        telemetry.update();
214  
215        // Change the Robot Controller's background color to match the color detected by the color sensor.
216        relativeLayout.post(new Runnable() {
217          public void run() {
218            relativeLayout.setBackgroundColor(Color.HSVToColor(hsvValues));
219          }
220        });
221      }
222    }
223  }
224
